column12: Recouped Broadway investment in ~10 weeks (often reported as '6 months' including Off-Broadway run at Public Theater). Currently grossing $600k+ weekly in profit. Multiple productions worldwide. Estimated total profit exceeds $1B.
Recouped in ~26 months (just over 2 years). Has grossed over $1.4B on Broadway alone. Film adaptation boosted 2024-2025 grosses significantly.

column11: Broadway's highest-grossing show of all time at $2B+. First show to hit $1B milestone (2013). Still running after 27+ years.

column12: Longest-running American musical in Broadway history. $700M+ Broadway gross. Low-cost concert staging was revolutionary. Weekly cost ~$250K. Recouped in 19 weeks (Mar 1997). $10M SVOG grant in 2021. Produced by Fran and Barry Weissler from Encores! concert.

column11: Recouped in ~9 months. Multiple touring and international productions. Investors received multiple returns.

First musical of 2018-2019 season to recoup. Won 8 Tony Awards including Best Musical. Recouped in ~30 weeks (6 months). Received $10M SVOG grant during COVID shutdown — one of at least 15 Broadway shows to receive the maximum grant. Grosses have softened recently but remains profitable. Received $10M federal SVOG grant during pandemic shutdown to support reopening.

column13: Recouped in ~16 months. Received $10M SVOG grant. Has grossed over $200M. National tour also profitable. Note: Jackson Estate receives 100% of producer profit share — actual investor returns depend on estate's profit participation terms; which are not publicly disclosed. Weekly cost ~$1.3M. Recouped Nov 2023. $10M SVOG grant. Jackson Estate negotiated 100% of lead-producer profits + 13% off-the-top after recoup+10%.

column12: Low capitalization + strong grosses = quick recoupment. Received $10M SVOG grant (200% of $5M capitalization — largest SVOG-to-cap ratio among tracked shows). Reopened Oct 2021; recouped ~Dec 2022. Multiple touring productions. Weekly cost ~$400K. Recouped Mar 2023 (600th performance). $10M SVOG grant.

column13: Recouped ~3 years after opening. Lavish production design. Has grossed $194M+ on Broadway. Received $9.9M SVOG grant + $15M insurance settlement during COVID shutdown. Estimated investor return 1.5-2.5x (Windfall confirmed). Closing April 2025. Weekly cost ~$1.3-1.4M. Recouped Nov 2022. $10M SVOG grant. $3M NY tax credit (among first to qualify).

column11: Fourth new musical to recoup post-pandemic. Max Martin jukebox catalogue drives consistent grosses.

Show: Harry Potter and the Cursed Child
column13: Most expensive play ever to recoup; but investor returns are minimal. Per Broadway Journal (Boroff; Dec 2025); only $2.3M in profit distributions to investors (6% return over 7 years). High insider profit share (31% of net profits); $34M+ in theater rent to ATG; and $10M+ in producer royalties/fees absorbed most of the $456M gross. Posted $3.5M operating loss year ending Feb 2025.

column12: Record 13 Tony nominations for a play. Recouped just before closing Jan 2025. National tour and West End transfer announced. Weekly cost ~$500K at Golden Theatre. Record 13 Tony nominations. Recouped Jan 8; 2025 during closing week.

column13: First show of 2024-2025 season to recoup. Transferred from sold-out Off-Broadway run. Set Lyceum box office records. Weekly cost ~$300K. First show of 2024-25 season to recoup (Nov 25; 2024). Broke Lyceum house gross record 10 times; most recently $1.226M/week.

column12: Closed Feb 22; 2026 without recouping. Returned ~60% of $22M to investors. Won 2 Tonys + Grammy. Alicia Keys had outsized insider profit participation: sole lead producer + underlying rights holder; earning 10% of net profits at recoupment (12.5% at 150%; 35% insider split at 200%). Similar structure to Harry Potter's Cursed Child. Had the show recouped; investors would have seen diluted returns. Weekly nut ~$750K. International productions planned may improve overall investor returns.

Show: Cabaret at the Kit Kat Club
column13: Closed Oct 2025 without recouping. Actual capitalization $24.25M (not $26M). $7.5M of investor money used to convert Kit Kat Club venue owned by ATG (the lead producer's parent company). Active investor lawsuit alleging producers used investor funds to improve their own real estate. Weekly nut $1.5M proved unsustainable. Investors received 0% recovery.

column12: Closed without recouping despite 7 Tony nominations. Spending not apparent in modest sets. Strong reviews couldn't overcome weak ticket sales.

column13: Won Tony for Best Original Score but closed Jan 2025 without recouping. Shaina Taub won two Tonys. Weekly cost ~$1.2-1.3M. Needed ~$1.4M/week to recoup in a year but averaged ~$1.0M. Hillary Clinton co-producer. 30+ cast.

Big-budget musical adaptation of Nicholas Sparks novel/film. $22-23M capitalization. Weekly cost ~$1.2-1.3M. Struggled to find audience; closed Dec 15; 2024 without recouping. Producers planned post-Broadway tour to recoup some costs.

Show: Back to the Future: The Musical
column11: Closed Jan 2025 after struggling to find audience. West End production more successful. High-tech production couldn't compensate for middling reviews.

column12: Big-budget extravaganza capitalized at $26M. Closed July 2025 after missing Tony momentum. Fixed weekly expenses of $817K. Jasmine Amy Rogers praised but couldn't save production.

column11: Star vehicle for Patti LuPone and Mia Farrow. Limited run closed as scheduled Jan 2025. Low capitalization ($4.8M) compared to other Broadway shows. Recoupment plausible but unverified by trade press — previous source was circular ('Inferred from Easy Winner designation').

column12: Jim Parsons-led revival at Barrymore Theatre. $5.5M capitalization. Played to ~95% capacity; grossed $1.084M in final week. Recouped during limited run ending Jan 19; 2025. Previous $20M figure was likely a data error.

Most expensive show of 2024-2025 season. Grossed $63M+ in 46 weeks with $1.0-1.1M weekly costs. On track to recoup Spring 2026. Eligible for $3M NY tax credit (25% of costs up to $12M). Break-even ~$1.2M weekly.

First Broadway musical led by Korean producer (OD Company). BroadwayWorld: 'now appears unlikely' to recoup - grosses declined ~$250K/week in 2025 vs 2024. Break-even ~$1.0M but recent weeks at $0.9M (82% capacity). Eligible for $3M NY tax credit. Lavish Jazz Age production with 22-person cast; Tony-winning costumes.

Won Best Musical Tony 2024. Recouped $22M investment week ending December 28; 2025 after 744 performances (89 weeks) and $121M+ total grosses. First new musical to recoup since Stranger Things (2022). Actors from developmental workshops entitled to profit-sharing per NYT.

column13: Netflix/Sonia Friedman production. Won 4 Tony Awards 2025. RECOUPED December 2025 - grossed $57M+ in 40 weeks with $1M/week costs = $17M+ profit toward $20M cap. Set Marquis Theatre record of $2.51M during Christmas week 2025. Season 5 finale boosted ticket sales significantly.

column12: Producer Orin Wolf noted it 'only cost $17 million' - modest for 2025 musical. Won 5 Tony Awards. Typical weekly gross $0.9-1.0M at 90-95% capacity. Break-even ~$0.85M. Broadway Journal: 'if they can weather the next year... may recoup in 12-18 months.' Eligible for $3M NY tax credit.

West End hit transferred to Broadway. Weekly costs $500K vs London's £100K. Break-even ~$600K weekly but averaging $580K - running below break-even. Extended through Feb 2026 on strong word-of-mouth despite soft grosses.

Jonathan Groff star vehicle. Bobby Darin jukebox musical with $9.4M cap and $600K weekly costs. Averaging $1.2M+ weekly gross - recoupment imminent (likely Feb 2026). Strong reviews and Groff's star power driving consistent sales.

Show: Two Strangers (Carry a Cake Across New York)
column12: Forbes: 'most investor friendly new musical since the pandemic' - $8M cap with $480K weekly nut (two-hander with minimal production). Break-even ~$550K. Typical gross $0.65-0.75M at 80-95% capacity. MISSED NY tax credit deadline (first paid performance Nov 1; 2025 was after Oct 20 cutoff). Despite modest grosses; low overhead means it's hovering near break-even.

Revival with Lea Michele and Aaron Tveit. Selling out regularly at ~$1.3-1.8M/week gross. Break-even ~$1.1M. Qualified for $3M NY theater tax credit (first preview Oct 15; 2025; just before Oct 20 deadline). At ~$500K weekly profit; could recoup by closing (June 14; 2026). Original 1988 production was $6M.

column10: Lincoln Center Theater revival. LCT operates on subscriber/nonprofit model - doesn't seek traditional recoupment. 32-member cast; 28-piece orchestra. Extended through June 2026. 100% capacity.

column12: Critics' Pick. Darren Criss + Helen J Shen. Small cast reduces running costs. Struggled financially early but has been selling out consistently.

Bess Wohl play; produced commercially by Daryl Roth. $5M capitalization. Weekly cost ~$500-600K. Grosses ~$540K/week at ~85% capacity; near breakeven. Ended limited run Feb 1; 2026 without recouping. Transferred from nonprofit origins.

Notes: Broadway premiere at MTC's Samuel J. Friedman Theatre. Tracy Letts play directed by David Cromer. Transferred from Steppenwolf. Carrie Coon stars. Critics' Pick.
Second Stage Theater production at Helen Hayes Theatre. Jordan Harrison play. Star cast: June Squibb; Cynthia Nixon; Danny Burstein. Critics' Pick.

column12: Mark Strong London transfer. $6.5M capitalization (SEC filings). Weekly cost ~$900K-1M. Grosses hovered near $937K/week; roughly breakeven. Limited run ended Feb 2026 without recouping. Investors likely lost capital.

Recouped within ~9 months (by mid-December 2014). Disney never announces recoupments -- per insider: 'recoupment is not a concept that makes sense in the Disney model' since they handle many services in-house. By May 2023: $561M+ grossed; 3;100+ performances. Received $3M NY theater tax credit. Disney's unique New Amsterdam lease pays 2% of gross as rent (vs standard fixed rent); affecting cost calculations.

column10: 25th Anniversary Tour Broadway engagement (Aug 2025 - Feb 2026). See mamma-mia-2001 for original production.

column12: Original production ran 14 years / 5;773 performances. Recouped within ~1 year. $7B+ grossed across all global productions. Weekly cost ~$400K. Recouped June 2002 (8 months). Ran 14 years in NYC. ABBA songwriters also served as lead producers.

column11: Closed early Dec 2025 after weak ticket sales. Stephen Schwartz score. Kristin Chenoweth star vehicle couldn't save production.

column12: Sequel to All In: Comedy About Love which recouped its $4.8M in just 10 weeks. Same format: rotating celebrity comedians with live band. Hit $2M+ weekly gross (record for a play). Very lean $200-300K weekly costs with 4-performer format. LIMITED RUN through March 8; 2026 - did NOT receive NY tax credit (missed application deadline by 2 months). Stars include Sarah Silverman; Ray Romano; Jason Mantzoukas.
Bobby Cannavale; James Corden; Jesse Tyler Harris revival. $6.9M capitalization. Recouped in final week of 16-week run (Dec 14; 2025). Averaged $1.2-1.8M grosses at ~99% capacity. Weekly cost ~$400K.

column11: Denzel Washington & Jake Gyllenhaal. $9M capitalization. Recouped in ~10 weeks (by May 1; 2025). Grosses routinely hit $2.8M/week. Premium tickets nearing $900. Highest-grossing play revival in world history.
Kieran Culkin; Bob Odenkirk; Bill Burr revival. $7.5M capitalization. Recouped in 9 weeks (by May 12; 2025). Weekly grosses peaked at $2.4M. Limited 16-week run.
Keanu Reeves and Alex Winter revival. Opened Sep 2025; recouped $7.5M investment by week ending Nov 19; 2025 (~8 weeks). Jamie Lloyd directed.

column12: Ben Platt-led revival of the 1998 Jason Robert Brown musical. $6.5M capitalization with $5.7M production costs. Weekly running cost ~$659K (Broadway Journal). Won Tony for Best Revival of a Musical 2023. Limited run March-August 2023 (~20 weeks). Received $3M NY state theater production tax credit; partially offsetting losses.

Based on the NBC TV series. SEC Form D shows $23M offering with ~$20M raised. Weekly operating costs ~$800K (per Reddit grosses analysis). Closed June 22; 2025 after Tony shutout — ran 32 previews and 84 performances at the Imperial Theatre. One of three $20M+ musicals that flopped in 2024-2025 season (alongside Boop! and Tammy Faye).

column13: Jamie Lloyd-directed revival starring Nicole Scherzinger. $15M capitalization. Weekly running cost ~$1M (industry estimate). Won Tony for Best Musical Revival 2025. Producer confirmed $6M loss despite selling out regularly and grossing $60M+ total. Jamie Lloyd had a $4M personal stake. Limited run at St. James Theatre. High production costs for the innovative minimalist staging with extensive video/tech. Highest gross of run was $2.5M in final week.

column12: Jeremy Strong and Michael Imperioli starred in Amy Herzog's new adaptation of the Ibsen classic. $5.5M capitalization recouped during the run at Circle in the Square Theatre. Broke Circle in the Square box office record. Strong won Tony for Best Actor in a Play.

Kit Connor and Rachel Zegler starred in Sam Gold's production at Circle in the Square Theatre. $7M capitalization fully recouped during extended; sold-out run. Total gross $21.8M. Highest gross of run was $1.48M in final week. Reported youngest average audience in Broadway history.

George Clooney's Broadway debut. Adapted from his 2005 film with Grant Heslov. $9.5M capitalization recouped in just 7.5 weeks at the Winter Garden Theatre — one of the fastest recoupments of the season. David Cromer directed. Broke Winter Garden box office record with $4.3M weekly gross.

column11: Idina Menzel star vehicle. New musical about Julia Butterfly Hill. Capitalized at up to $16M per SEC filing. Average gross ~$760K/week at 85% capacity; $105 ATP. Closed May 18; 2025 following Tony nomination snub. NYT Critics' Pick but couldn't sustain sales.

column12: Sutton Foster-led Encores! transfer to Hudson Theatre. $8M capitalization (unconfirmed industry estimate; not from SEC filing). Weekly running cost ~$625K (industry estimate). Average gross ~$760K/week at 92% capacity; $110 ATP. Limited run Aug-Nov 2024 (~16 weeks). Amy Sherman-Palladino adapted the book. Encores! origins kept costs relatively lean for a musical.

Notes: Reimagined immersive production of Cats. Opening April 7; 2026 at PAC NYC. Transferred from sold-out Perelman Performing Arts Center run. Financial details not yet publicly available.

column11: Revival of David Auburn Pulitzer Prize-winning play. $9M capitalization (planned offering). Limited 16-week run Apr-Jul 2026. Co-produced by Mike Bosner and Thomas Kail.
